Failing to cooperate with WHS inspectors

 

In 2013, salon owners John Chalhoub and Bakhos Khalil were fined $3,500 and $2,350 respectively, and ordered to pay over $2,000 in costs after abusing WHS inspectors.

 

The inspectors were attempting to follow up on previous WHS compliance matters with Mr Chalhoub, who had failed to have a workers' compensation policy in place, or comply with the terms of an improvement notice regarding workplace bullying.

 

Mr Chalhoub became violent during the incident. He called one inspector a series of derogatory names and told the inspector he was “going to snap” and “beat [the inspector] up”. Mr Khalil also grabbed the other inspector’s arm.

 

Both men were charged with obstructing and intimidating the inspectors in the exercise of their functions under WHS laws.

Powers of entry

An inspector is permitted to enter a workplace at any time without prior notice. The inspector must notify the PCBU; the person with management or control of the workplace; and any health and safety representatives as soon as practicable after entry – unless this would defeat the purpose of the entry.

 

Powers upon entry

An inspector has broad powers upon entering the workplace, including:

 

•

inspecting and making inquiries at the workplace

•

examining any object or document

•

taking measurements, conducting tests or making recordings (including photographs or videos or other digital recordings)

•

removing and analysing a sample of any substance or thing

•

requiring people at the workplace to give reasonable help in performing these activities

•

exercising compliance powers reasonably necessary for the purposes of the WHS Act

 

Any person who fails to give reasonable help required by an inspector may be fined up to a maximum of $10,000. A corporation may be fined up to a maximum of $50,000.

A PCBU is a Person Conduct a Business or Undertaking. In Victoria, the PCBU/worker relationship is the employer/employee relationship

 

(Victoria: $9100)

 

(Victoria: $45,501)
